MA 104: Ordinary Differential Equations - Lecture 7

Related: MA 104 Course Overview | Lecture 6 - MA104 | Lecture 8 - MA104

Variation of Parameters (Lagrange)

Limitation of Undetermined Coefficients:
  • Requires constant coefficients $P,Q$.
  • $R(x)$ must be exponential/polynomial/sin-cos (or products).
  • Fails for variable coefficients, e.g., $y'' + y = \tan x$.
New method works for the general nonhomogeneous equation $$ y'' + P(x)y' + Q(x)y = R(x) \tag{1} $$ where $P,Q,R$ are continuous on open interval $I$. Assumption: Know two linearly independent solutions $y_1,y_2$ of the homogeneous equation $$ y'' + P(x)y' + Q(x)y = 0 \tag{2} $$ Goal: Find particular solution of form $$ y_p(x) = v_1(x) y_1(x) + v_2(x) y_2(x) \tag{3} $$ (vary the constants $c_1,c_2$ into functions $v_1,v_2$).

Derivation

Differentiate (3): $$ y_p' = v_1' y_1 + v_1 y_1' + v_2' y_2 + v_2 y_2' $$ Impose condition (avoids second derivatives of $v_i$): $$ v_1' y_1 + v_2' y_2 = 0 \tag{4} $$ Then $$ y_p'' = v_1' y_1' + v_1 y_1'' + v_2' y_2' + v_2 y_2'' $$

Substitute into (1). Homogeneous parts cancel, leaving $$ v1' y1' + v2' y2' = R(x) \tag{5} $$

Solve system (4)+(5) using Wronskian $W = y1 y2' - y1' y2 \neq 0$: $$ v1' = -\frac{y2 R}{W}, \quad v2' = \frac{y1 R}{W} $$ Integrate: $$ v1 = -\int \frac{y2 R}{W}\, dx, \quad v2 = \int \frac{y1 R}{W}\, dx $$ Particular solution: $$ yp = y2 \int \frac{y1 R}{W}\, dx - y1 \int \frac{y_2 R}{W}\, dx $$

General solution of (1): $$ y = c_1 y_1 + c_2 y_2 + y_p $$

Example

$$ y'' + y = \sec x $$ Homogeneous: $y_1 = \cos x$, $y_2 = \sin x$, $W=1$

$$ v1' = -\sin x \sec x = -\tan x \implies v1 = \ln|\cos x| $$ $$ v2' = 1 \implies v2 = x $$ $$ yp = \cos x \ln|\cos x| + x \sin x $$ General solution: $$ y = c1 \cos x + c_2 \sin x + \cos x \ln|\cos x| + x \sin x $$

Higher-Order Linear ODEs

General form: $$ P_n(x) y^{(n)} + P_{n-1}(x) y^{(n-1)} + \cdots + P_0(x) y = R(x) $$ Standard form: $$ y^{(n)} + p_{n-1}(x) y^{(n-1)} + \cdots + p_0(x) y = R(x) $$
  • Homogeneous if $R\equiv 0$.
  • A solution is an $n$-times differentiable function satisfying the equation identically.
Linearity Principle: Linear combinations of homogeneous solutions are solutions. Linear Independence (n functions on $I$): $c_1 y_1 + \cdots + c_n y_n \equiv 0 \implies$ all $c_i=0$. Basis (Fundamental set): $n$ linearly independent solutions. General solution (homogeneous): $y_h = c_1 y_1 + \cdots + c_n y_n$. General solution (nonhomogeneous): $y = y_p + y_h$.

Initial Value Problem (n-th Order)

$$ y(x0)=y0,\ y'(x0)=y1,\ \dots,\ y^{(n-1)}(x0)=y{n-1} $$

Existence & Uniqueness: If coefficients $p_{n-1},\dots,p_0$ continuous on open $I\ni x_0$, then unique solution on entire $I$.

Wronskian for n Functions

$$ W(y1,\dots,yn)(x) = \det\begin{vmatrix} y1 & \cdots & yn \\ y1' & \cdots & yn' \\ \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ y1^{(n-1)} & \cdots & yn^{(n-1)} \end{vmatrix} $$

Theorem (solutions of linear homogeneous ODE with continuous coefficients): The $n$ solutions are linearly dependent on $I$ ‚áî $W\equiv 0$ on $I$. If $W(x_0)\neq 0$, they form a basis on $I$.

Homogeneous Constant-Coefficient Equations

$$ y^{(n)} + a{n-1} y^{(n-1)} + \cdots + a0 y = 0 $$

Characteristic equation: $$ r^n + a_{n-1} r^{n-1} + \cdots + a_0 = 0 $$ Basis:
  • Distinct real roots $r_k$: $\{e^{r_k x}\}$
  • Real root $r$ multiplicity $m$: $\{e^{rx}, x e^{rx}, \dots, x^{m-1} e^{rx}\}$
  • Simple complex $\alpha\pm i\beta$: $\{e^{\alpha x}\cos\beta x, e^{\alpha x}\sin\beta x\}$
  • Complex multiplicity $m$: Multiply by $x^k$ ($k=0,\dots,m-1$) for cos/sin terms.

Nonhomogeneous ‚Äì Undetermined Coefficients (Higher Order)

Same Basic Rule, Sum Rule, Modification Rule as 2nd order.

Modification: Multiply guessed term by smallest power of $x$ so it is independent of homogeneous solution. Example: $$ y''' + 3y'' + 3y' + y = 30 e^{-x} $$ with $y(0)=3$, $y'(0)=-3$, $y''(0)=-47$. Characteristic: $(r+1)^3=0$ (triple root $-1$). $y_h = (c_1 + c_2 x + c_3 x^2)e^{-x}$ Guess $y_p = C x^3 e^{-x}$ (√ó$x^3$). Substitute into ODE ‚Üí solve for $C$.

Summary of Lecture 7

  • Variation of Parameters: General method using two homogeneous solutions and Wronskian.
Formula: $y_p = y_2\int\frac{y_1 R}{W}\,dx - y_1\int\frac{y_2 R}{W}\,dx$.
  • Higher-order theory: Wronskian detects independence; existence/uniqueness when coefficients continuous.
  • Constant coefficients: Characteristic polynomial ‚Üí basis according to root type (real/complex, multiplicity).
  • Nonhomogeneous: $y = y_h + y_p$; undetermined coefficients with modification for higher multiplicity.
Next: More on higher-order (Cauchy-Euler, systems) and applications.
